body_html:
@PhilipMay using conda to install tensorflow does matter.
Conda TF package is built and maintained by anaconda. That is clearly stated in our documentation, in the same page you linked:
https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_linux#InstallingAnaconda

Please reach out to anaconda for support with the conda package.
Just for good measure, I also just verified that the pip package on pypi for tensorflow runs on cuda 9.0:

$ pip3 install tensorflow-gpu --upgrade
$ python3
>>> import tensorflow as tf
>>> tf.test.is_gpu_available()
....
True
>>> exit()
$ nvcc --version
nvcc: NVIDIA (R) Cuda compiler driver
Copyright (c) 2005-2017 NVIDIA Corporation
Built on Thu_Oct_19_03:08:58_CDT_2017
Cuda compilation tools, release 9.0, V9.0.222

Closing this issue, as it is about the community supported conda package.

body:
@PhilipMay using conda to install tensorflow does matter.
Conda TF package is built and maintained by anaconda. That is clearly stated in our documentation, in the same page you linked:
https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_linux#InstallingAnaconda

Please reach out to anaconda for support with the conda package.
Just for good measure, I also just verified that the pip package on pypi for tensorflow runs on cuda 9.0:
```
$ pip3 install tensorflow-gpu --upgrade
$ python3
>>> import tensorflow as tf
>>> tf.test.is_gpu_available()
....
True
>>> exit()
$ nvcc --version
nvcc: NVIDIA (R) Cuda compiler driver
Copyright (c) 2005-2017 NVIDIA Corporation
Built on Thu_Oct_19_03:08:58_CDT_2017
Cuda compilation tools, release 9.0, V9.0.222
```

Closing this issue, as it is about the community supported conda package.
